content.description: Humans vary in their ability to taste the bitter chemical compound phenylthiocarbamide (<math alttext="P T C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PTC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The taster phenotype is dominant to the nontaster phenotype. Researchers tested the <math alttext="P T C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PTC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> taster phenotype of individuals from an isolated population. In the sample, 780 individuals were able to taste <math alttext="P T C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PTC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and 70 individuals were not able to taste <math alttext="P T C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>PTC</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: Assuming the population is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, what is the frequency of the non-taster allele?
